author: beefstake
body:
Materials sector will get decimated once supply glut hits.

Right now commodities prices are at ATH because of massive undersupply. However supply is getting built out at a crazy rate and the demand spike for a lot of these goods is likely temporary.
This isn't new or unusual, commodities super-cycles are they are known are fairly frequent phenomena. Some people get very rich on the way up, some people get left with some very heavy bags and a few people get very rich on the way down.

Correction in commodities pricing will be violent and brutal. Similar to the bond market commodities are traded using highly levered products called futures so when the crash starts happening (it already has) it will go down very fast.

The other bubble which is probably a year or 2 out from peaking is semiconductor stocks. For now supply is constrained but fabs are being built out massively on a scale never seen before. Again this isn't new, semis have a boom/bust cycle like commodities. It's just this one is much bigger and will take longer to play out.

Unlike commodities, bonds or crypto this one will take a lot longer to deflate. I expect NVDA, AMAT and ASML to be hit the hardest by this. NVDA is going to get a double whammy from their 30XX series lining up with the top of the boom and crypto cycle exploding likely dumping tons of cheap 2nd hand hardware on the market.

author: CallLivesMatter
body:
Look for companies with pricing power within their market. KO has insane price elasticity to demand. WM is really strong because everyone just pays their garbage bill. Nobody shops around to see if a competitor is $1.50/mo cheaper. OSK and URI are great ways to play the construction/improvement trend and rental equipment costs get passed on pretty easily. AMAT and ASML are both serving a high demand industry and as such they have strong pricing power. Probably two dozen other names that fit easily into this (very simplified) strategy.

*Disclosure: This is not a solicitation to buy or sell any security. Do your own damn homework you lazy ass*.

author: JayArlington
body:
Before a single new chip is made with this investment, it is the capital equipment manufacturers that will benefit FIRST.  

ASML, AMAT, KLAC, KLIC, LRCX

This will not help NVDA, QCOM, or AMD until new fab capacity is online (so end of 2022 at the earliest).  Once more fab capacity has been created, the chip designers should benefit from lower contract manufacturing prices.

author: seigy
body:
This needs to be repeated loudly and often.  Do not chase what is already over-done!  Chasing often results in buying high and selling low.  
Look for solid companies with a sound business and plenty of future growth.  Learn to always check p/e and p/s ratios before buying.  See what the stock traded prior to covid, did they launch something new or improve their business during covid?  If not, why would the company be worth more now than it was pre-covid?  Always have a hold philosophy before buying (is it 5 weeks, 5 months, or 5 years before you think you may want to sell it?)  
Now is a great time to start buying some of the big tech and some of the other moderate p/e tech companies that will be long-term (3+ year) winners like AMD, SKWS, TSM, LRCX, AMAT.  This does not mean go all in on them but rather start buying with a plan.  Look at the solar and green-tech companies, if you find something with a p/e below ~40, research it maybe buy a few share and keep it on the radar.  Now is a great time to start buying small positions in longterm winners that have been beaten up.  This however, is not a time I could recommend looking at too many things that are still unproven.  That doesn't mean you shouldn't look at small positions in things like weed, on-line betting, eV, big data, just keep those risks as a small part of your portfolio.

author: NaQuaDa_
body:
Hi all,

I'm (37) European with a fairly stable income decided to start investing at the end of January. I decided to allocate around 10% of my monthly income with the main objective of building up a pension fund. I don't have big debts besides the mortgage which takes around 15% of my monthly income.
As I don't have to pay taxes in capital gains (up to 100k and from there only 4%) decided to start with mostly stocks. I don't plan tu touch the investment unless an urgency happens as I can pay all the other things with the monthly income.
I can tolerate some risk but want to play something with the right risk/reward balance.
At the moment I don't have anything else, besides the house I'm paying mortgage for.
My main problem is that my experience with the stock market is not going as supposed. I mostly only invested in companies that I know because of my job and believe in (biggest positions are in Semiconductor: ASML, Micron, NVIDIA, AMAT; Renewable: Enphase, sunrun; EV: Tesla; e-commerce: Amazon, SE Ltd; Health: TMO, Teladoc and Fintech: eToro SPAC. (Biggest positions are Enphase, Amazon, TMO and Nvidia). However, since I joined, I "lost" around 25%.

I know it was a bad moment to start investing and likely the market will continue a bull run that will make me recover the lost. But I start wondering if the stock market is the right place to invest or should I try something else or some other strategy (i.e. instead of investing monthly, accumulate funds for when I see a crash/big correction).

Thank you for your help!

author: ScarletHark
body:
Taiwan has this little issue called "China" 100 miles off its coast, and China has been rattling sabers in Taiwan's direction for the past few weeks -- likely just to see what Washington's reaction is, but China is desperate for chipmaking capability, has failed constantly in developing the technology/know-how themselves, and would probably like nothing more than to do to Taiwan what it did to Hong Kong. 

I don't think that China will actually attack Taiwan because Xi knows that it's an open declaration of hot war on the entire world (not just the U.S.) but the threat is there -- the entire world's economy literally depends on Xi not going full Kim Jong Un level of insane on us. 

Business-wise -- TSMC is completely booked; any new capacity they manage to scrape together is immediately snatched up. TSMC has stated that prices will go up for new orders, but they are still working through the backlog that has been under contract for some time, and the new pricing won't take effect yet. This, plus the threat of China, is what's keeping the $TSM price depressed right now. Beyond that, they have nothing but tailwinds from a business perspective for the next several years. 

Look for the semicaps ($AMAT, $ASML, $TER, $LRCX, $KLAC, et al) if you want plays that will see action first from the TSMC, Intel and Samsung capex spending. The fabs will benefit from this capex second, while the fabless companies ($NVDA, $AMD, $AAPL, etc.) will see the benefit of this extra capacity last.

author: Spec-Chum
body:
Aside from the more obvious TSM, NVDA and AMD, there's also  AMAT, LRCX, ASML and TER as semiconductor fab plays.

I'd maybe be slightly cautious of TSM in the short term as they're already over capacity, so upside is limited, but very decent long term as they expand into a US fab.

This is where AMAT, LRCX, ASML and TER come into play; they should gain when any chip fab expands, be it Intel, TSMC or Samsung.

Another one to watch is UMC, they're kinda like TSM's baby brother; they're well behind on the fab tech, but don't rule them out.  They got battered yesterday, but I feel will rebound well.

author: millennial-snowflake
body: I'm not sure I'd call it a beating since I'm still way up in most Semiconductors in the last year or so. That said I think it's a great opportunity for chipmaking suppliers like AMAT (I'm up 140% this year) ... A lot of chip makers cut their estimates and inventory in the covid market scare last year, so now they're rushing to gear up supply since people are spending like crazy, on everything from toasters to cars to crypto miners and game consoles.  Crypto mining has definitely played a part in eating up chip supply and as blockchains switch to proof of stake such as ETH's did with ETH2 that'll lessen.

author: r0botdevil
body:
I've got a pretty steady upward trend over the last year. I got three *awful* tips from my dad that are just tanking so far (he's usually pretty savvy but boy did he shit the bed with these), but most of the rest of it is doing well.

Most of it is in pretty boring stocks like Berkshire Hathaway, Goodyear Tires, Boeing, Applied Materials, Weyerhauser, Intel, Costco, etc. Hell I'm up 98% on my Hawaiian Airlines shares that I bought late last year.

I think the key is that I've got stock in dozens of companies spread out across a dozen different industries, so when any given industry is hitting the skids I'm diversified enough to barely notice it. I'm not gonna retire young with this kind of investment strategy, but I am gonna be able to retire pretty easily at a pretty normal age.

author: beefstake
body:
Materials sector will get decimated once supply glut hits.

Right now commodities prices are at ATH because of massive undersupply. However supply is getting built out at a crazy rate and the demand spike for a lot of these goods is likely temporary.
This isn't new or unusual, commodities super-cycles are they are known are fairly frequent phenomena. Some people get very rich on the way up, some people get left with some very heavy bags and a few people get very rich on the way down.

Correction in commodities pricing will be violent and brutal. Similar to the bond market commodities are traded using highly levered products called futures so when the crash starts happening (it already has) it will go down very fast.

The other bubble which is probably a year or 2 out from peaking is semiconductor stocks. For now supply is constrained but fabs are being built out massively on a scale never seen before. Again this isn't new, semis have a boom/bust cycle like commodities. It's just this one is much bigger and will take longer to play out.

Unlike commodities, bonds or crypto this one will take a lot longer to deflate. I expect NVDA, AMAT and ASML to be hit the hardest by this. NVDA is going to get a double whammy from their 30XX series lining up with the top of the boom and crypto cycle exploding likely dumping tons of cheap 2nd hand hardware on the market.

author: CallLivesMatter
body:
Look for companies with pricing power within their market. KO has insane price elasticity to demand. WM is really strong because everyone just pays their garbage bill. Nobody shops around to see if a competitor is $1.50/mo cheaper. OSK and URI are great ways to play the construction/improvement trend and rental equipment costs get passed on pretty easily. AMAT and ASML are both serving a high demand industry and as such they have strong pricing power. Probably two dozen other names that fit easily into this (very simplified) strategy.

*Disclosure: This is not a solicitation to buy or sell any security. Do your own damn homework you lazy ass*.

author: JayArlington
body:
Before a single new chip is made with this investment, it is the capital equipment manufacturers that will benefit FIRST.  

ASML, AMAT, KLAC, KLIC, LRCX

This will not help NVDA, QCOM, or AMD until new fab capacity is online (so end of 2022 at the earliest).  Once more fab capacity has been created, the chip designers should benefit from lower contract manufacturing prices.

author: seigy
body:
This needs to be repeated loudly and often.  Do not chase what is already over-done!  Chasing often results in buying high and selling low.  
Look for solid companies with a sound business and plenty of future growth.  Learn to always check p/e and p/s ratios before buying.  See what the stock traded prior to covid, did they launch something new or improve their business during covid?  If not, why would the company be worth more now than it was pre-covid?  Always have a hold philosophy before buying (is it 5 weeks, 5 months, or 5 years before you think you may want to sell it?)  
Now is a great time to start buying some of the big tech and some of the other moderate p/e tech companies that will be long-term (3+ year) winners like AMD, SKWS, TSM, LRCX, AMAT.  This does not mean go all in on them but rather start buying with a plan.  Look at the solar and green-tech companies, if you find something with a p/e below ~40, research it maybe buy a few share and keep it on the radar.  Now is a great time to start buying small positions in longterm winners that have been beaten up.  This however, is not a time I could recommend looking at too many things that are still unproven.  That doesn't mean you shouldn't look at small positions in things like weed, on-line betting, eV, big data, just keep those risks as a small part of your portfolio.

author: NaQuaDa_
body:
Hi all,

I'm (37) European with a fairly stable income decided to start investing at the end of January. I decided to allocate around 10% of my monthly income with the main objective of building up a pension fund. I don't have big debts besides the mortgage which takes around 15% of my monthly income.
As I don't have to pay taxes in capital gains (up to 100k and from there only 4%) decided to start with mostly stocks. I don't plan tu touch the investment unless an urgency happens as I can pay all the other things with the monthly income.
I can tolerate some risk but want to play something with the right risk/reward balance.
At the moment I don't have anything else, besides the house I'm paying mortgage for.
My main problem is that my experience with the stock market is not going as supposed. I mostly only invested in companies that I know because of my job and believe in (biggest positions are in Semiconductor: ASML, Micron, NVIDIA, AMAT; Renewable: Enphase, sunrun; EV: Tesla; e-commerce: Amazon, SE Ltd; Health: TMO, Teladoc and Fintech: eToro SPAC. (Biggest positions are Enphase, Amazon, TMO and Nvidia). However, since I joined, I "lost" around 25%.

I know it was a bad moment to start investing and likely the market will continue a bull run that will make me recover the lost. But I start wondering if the stock market is the right place to invest or should I try something else or some other strategy (i.e. instead of investing monthly, accumulate funds for when I see a crash/big correction).

Thank you for your help!

author: ScarletHark
body:
Taiwan has this little issue called "China" 100 miles off its coast, and China has been rattling sabers in Taiwan's direction for the past few weeks -- likely just to see what Washington's reaction is, but China is desperate for chipmaking capability, has failed constantly in developing the technology/know-how themselves, and would probably like nothing more than to do to Taiwan what it did to Hong Kong. 

I don't think that China will actually attack Taiwan because Xi knows that it's an open declaration of hot war on the entire world (not just the U.S.) but the threat is there -- the entire world's economy literally depends on Xi not going full Kim Jong Un level of insane on us. 

Business-wise -- TSMC is completely booked; any new capacity they manage to scrape together is immediately snatched up. TSMC has stated that prices will go up for new orders, but they are still working through the backlog that has been under contract for some time, and the new pricing won't take effect yet. This, plus the threat of China, is what's keeping the $TSM price depressed right now. Beyond that, they have nothing but tailwinds from a business perspective for the next several years. 

Look for the semicaps ($AMAT, $ASML, $TER, $LRCX, $KLAC, et al) if you want plays that will see action first from the TSMC, Intel and Samsung capex spending. The fabs will benefit from this capex second, while the fabless companies ($NVDA, $AMD, $AAPL, etc.) will see the benefit of this extra capacity last.

author: Spec-Chum
body:
Aside from the more obvious TSM, NVDA and AMD, there's also  AMAT, LRCX, ASML and TER as semiconductor fab plays.

I'd maybe be slightly cautious of TSM in the short term as they're already over capacity, so upside is limited, but very decent long term as they expand into a US fab.

This is where AMAT, LRCX, ASML and TER come into play; they should gain when any chip fab expands, be it Intel, TSMC or Samsung.

Another one to watch is UMC, they're kinda like TSM's baby brother; they're well behind on the fab tech, but don't rule them out.  They got battered yesterday, but I feel will rebound well.

author: millennial-snowflake
body: I'm not sure I'd call it a beating since I'm still way up in most Semiconductors in the last year or so. That said I think it's a great opportunity for chipmaking suppliers like AMAT (I'm up 140% this year) ... A lot of chip makers cut their estimates and inventory in the covid market scare last year, so now they're rushing to gear up supply since people are spending like crazy, on everything from toasters to cars to crypto miners and game consoles.  Crypto mining has definitely played a part in eating up chip supply and as blockchains switch to proof of stake such as ETH's did with ETH2 that'll lessen.

author: polaarbear
body:
It's not...the...same. AMD's chiplet approach allows them to get drastically higher yields because they can marry 4-core (and now 8-core) blocks of high-binned chiplets to get those 64-core CPUs.

Intel is still manufacturing monolithic dies. They make a 28 core CPU, and one core comes out defective, and well, fuck, that's not a 28 core CPU anymore.  This portion of the manufacturing process has NOTHING to do with the node size.

Intel is working on something tangential called Foveros that's been in development for awhile to allow layering of the chips.  They are also experimenting with some big.LITTLE type designs that are looking extremely promising.

Again, NONE of these things are linked to the node size.  You are comparing Apples to Oranges and then proudly rolling out your victory chariot like you are some sort of genius when really you just look ignorant.

https://www.anandtech.com/show/15877/intel-hybrid-cpu-lakefield-all-you-need-to-know/2

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xz3Kwi45gHk

It's literally the exact 30-billion dollar investment that is being discussed.

author: Mail_Order_Lutefisk
body:
>Remember that stock losses are temporary

This is not always true. If you are in the broader market, yes, it will in all likelihood recover. If you are in individual names, nope, no guarantee. 

If you bought General Motors in 1980, that stock is worth nothing today. Nothing. It went bankrupt. Sure, you pulled out some dividends, but the principal is toast. Buying GM in 1980 was sound, sage advice. 

If you bought Intel in the summer of 2000 when it was the darling you are still down. JDSU bagholders are out a lot as well. I cannot state how much people loved JDSU back in the day. 

I personally went ballz deep in Citigroup, AIG and Lehman when they were falling knives. LEH is gone and C and AIG did reverse splits and are worth maybe 20% of what I paid for them in 2007 or 2008. 

Moral of the story, if you are in individual names, watch them like a freaking hawk because some of those losses, even in "great names" will never come back. And in a frothy and highly speculative market like this one with "pre-earnings" companies commanding market caps deep into the billions, risk is increased exponentially.

author: polaarbear
body:
You are ex-fucking-xactly right. And the 64 core AMD CPU costs $7500 dollars whereas the 28 core Intel can be had for ~3K right now. In scenarios where you would install one 64-core EPYC, you instead get a dual-socket motherboard and install a pair of the 28-core Xeons giving you 56-cores total in the same amount of space as the 64-core CPU.

You guys are treating this all like it's your gaming desktop. That's not how the enterprise works, not everything is a single-socket motherboard with dual-channel RAM.  There are I/O implications, memory bandwidth limitations.  You can't compare the 64-core AMD benchmark to the 28-core Intel benchmark and be like "Look AMD da best man."  When you compare the 64-core AMD vs a 56-core Intel installation (similar *cost*) the gap is like 15% instead of 50%, and there is a lot more calculated into the platform cost than a single CPU alone.

author: DotComBomb1999
body:
It feels a lot like Feb 2000, when the dot com bubble was about to burst. I was in the thick of it... I was running a startup hoping to IPO, and I had dozens of friends who were paper millionaires with their stock options, and most wound up worthless. I started with $5k in 1998, and by 2000, I had over $200k in my Schwab account. I thought I had cracked the code, and I was feeling pretty invincible.

In Feb 2000, I shorted some tech stocks, then bailed when they kept going up and took my losses. As the bubble started to burst, I put all my money in "safe" profitable tech stocks (Cisco, Oracle, Network Solutions and Intel). A month later the bottom fell out. It was a roller coaster ride, with enough ups to make you think it was coming back. My "safe" stocks lost a bundle. I rode two companies into the ground, and lost 90% on others. 

Today, Cisco and Oracle are worth less than they were 21 years ago. Despite consistent earnings increases, they never grew into those valuations. (Yes, I wish I had put everything in AAPL, GOOG and AMZN instead).This market feels "frothy" (to quote someone smarter than I am). There will always be winners and losers, but when the market loses its collective mind every time someone says "inflation" or "tightening" it's concerning. I'm still long, but it seems like it's time to think about taking some chips off the table soon.

author: Vegetable_Vanilla_74
body:
Response to this.  No position either way. For Intel,   I do know however that as you increase your technode you must increase your equipment technology.  20 B for new Fabs is not an eye shocking number and anyone who knows semiconductor companies knows this.  

Look at the foundry TSMC majority of output is in Taiwan with only 2 8-inch wafer facilities in the USA.   8 inch wafer facilities are money losers, you spend the same amount to produce them as a 12 inch wafer, but netting less chips, industry current standard or 300 mm or 12 inch.  Those fabs wont be around much longer and they will eventually need to be retooled, and most likely completely rebuilt.    

Why building in the USA will be so important in the future.   

Look at Taiwan and Singapore two places China would love to control.  Let's say tensions with China intensify and a skirmish or war breaks out there.   There would be a strangle on a lot of chip manufacturing.  Pay attention to trouble brewing in the south china sea.  

If Intels fabs are up and running they would continue to build un-harrassed in the USA.   

I agree that any time a company takes money for capital expenditures when it is running behind is risky. TSMC IS SPENDING 25 TO 28 BILLION THIS YEAR ON CAPITAL EXPENSES.  Samsung  is spending 28.1 billion this year. The reason Intel is producing more fabrication facilities is so that is can have more capacity which it does not have access to currently.  So the numbers being thrown around are normal for the industry.   

I would have to agree in the short term intel is behind and it will take time for them to get back up.   I do however believe they will be much better positioned going forward.   Their stock already looks discounted. 

Just remember semiconductor companies are always playing texas hold em.   They have to put tons of money upfront and then hope everything works out to stay profitable.   Loss of power, interuptions in supply chain i.e. south china sea, would be devastating to any company producing there.  

The only thing that would push intel higher right now would be an announcement of more capacity,  upgrading to 450 mm wafers, or some new advanced processes that blows away the competition.   They are making more capacity but that yield will be 18 months or more out.  Not a bull or bear hear just my two cents.

author: cwdawg15
body:
Sometimes being a consumer of a company can help you see some trends that can help you find a good purchase, but over time learn to separate your outlook on various companies between your perception as an investor and as a consumer.

I bought a laptop with an Intel chip this year, but I got over $20k in AMD.

A few fundamentals I see some young investors struggle with, myself in the past included, is understanding P/E, revenue, and net profit. But more importantly, go a step further and understand what competitive advantages a company has to gain future profits without the rise in competition from other companies that will undercut them. Certain companies can find ways to get more pricing power in contracts with other companies or be able to price a little higher with consumers. 

Firstly, since the peak in February I'm up 9%, something to keep in mind. 

These high-growth companies everyone gets excited about should be a part of your investment portfolio, but only a part. Many of them will fail or one day be out-competed by another company, while 1 will remain as the next big thing. They're riskier and more volatile in the interim. They haven't made it yet, they're just on the cusp of maybe making it. Look beyond just the recent price performance of the stock.

&#x200B;

Take CHWY as an example.  They've yet to make a profit. Let me say that again, they've yet to make a profit.

In 2020 They had revenue's of $4.85B, but their net income with expenses was -$252.37m. 

They still need to do 1 of 3 things generally speaking:

1) Get pricing negotiation power over suppliers to get a higher cut of the products they are retailing.

2) Get a higher price from consumers that are buying the product

3) Get more efficiencies to lower expenses per amount of revenue they take in.

CHWY is getting traction on their stock price, because they are on the edge of being able to turn a profit and possibly grow larger, but they haven't yet.

If there is any small downtrend in the market, stocks like this are bound to fall faster and deeper. Investor's are paying a premium for a stock that might turn a profit later.

In the meantime, they offer no dividend, so the stock doesn't give the investor anything back directly. The fwd P/E ratio, with analyst expectations they will be profitable in 2022, is still $442.89 (CFRA).  This means you are paying $442.89 for each $1 they earn. That is extremely high. To be worth the current price, not only do they need to start turning a profit, they need a high enough profit to make that P/E ratio lower between $15-$35.

This tells me any little news that shows forward momentum of improvement will make investors get excited, but any bad news on the macro-economy or about their suppliers, consumers, or the company can cause larger drops in the price.

&#x200B;

An example of a growing retail company that is a more stable investment is TSCO, Tractor Supply Company. They have a growing consumer market on the exurban edge of large and mid-size cities. One of the fewer places brick and mortar retailers have room for growth.

This is an example of a company that has made it, has room for growth, and the stock is paying out.

They have had several years of sustained profits. In 2020 They have a revenue of $10.6B and a net profit of $749m. 

The stock is paying a divided to shareholders just over 1% annually.  The P/E ratio is 26.87. This means for each $26.87 in the cost of the stock the company is making $1 after expenses.

What to expect is there is room for growth and room for the stock to go down, like any company. But it will be less volatile than CHWY. If there is a small hiccup in the macro-economy investors won't be as nervous. It's a stable company turning a profit that can justify its price without as much future growth. Whereas, CHWY depends on that future growth that is in jeopardy.

This exercise isn't about saying TSCO is better than CHWY or the opposite. That is not the point and I'd be interested in buying both.

But this is an exercise in understanding and managing risk. I was some riskier companies with real potential, but I choose carefully what % of my portfolio are those types of companies. I have other parts of my portfolio that are growth companies that have already achieved success and have lower P/E ratios, but are less risky during small downturns.

Then I have another portion of my portfolio that are value companies. These are stable companies that I don't expect much growth (beyond growth from inflation), in fact some are slowly in decline, but they're stable, common to consumers and produce dividends. Sometimes just 2-3%, but sometimes 7%. That is annual income from the stocks, not tied to changes in the share price at all.

&#x200B;

There are two important sides to investing, 1) finding companies that will grow and 2) managing the overall risk you're taking in finding that growth.

It is easy to find growing companies during a long Bull Market, but these popular companies with these large potential upsides in stock price are the riskiest during a bear market or even a small downturn. You're not paying for the profits they are making now, you're paying a huge premium for profits you believe they will be making in 5-6 years vs. a company that is making the profits now.

So don't just look at the performance of a stock by share price over the last few years, rather look at it on a broader level of how much that company is making for that share price and how down it will probably go in a downturn.

&#x200B;

I might buy some CHWY myself for my riskier portfolio allotments, but I know their profits haven't come close to justifying that price. It is priced at profit potential 2-3 years out and any sign of a potential downturn or problem will cause some volatile dips that aren't always guaranteed to recover.

(Side note: I'm long on TSCO. I needed a good comparison to examine risk. At it's current price, I believe it to be slightly overvalued. It has been a good long-term investment.)

author: Dwigt_Schroot
body:
Anyone who thinks that Intel is "dYiNg CoMpAnY" is very high on something. Intel has a very wide moat (their fabs) which has given them some trouble for the past 5 years. Looks like they are poised to turn the corner and be on the path to getting higher-end process technology working again.

* Only US Chip manufacturer with high-end processor manufacturing skills and capacity
* Despite delays in the manufacturing process, they have maintained competitiveness in processor performance with sheer optimizations of their 14nm process (I call that innovation)
* Still has >92% server market and regained some lost desktop market in Q4 2020
* 4th or 5th largest R&D spending per year in the world
* Has complete ecosystem of products around a CPU (chipsets, ethernet, wifi, etc.....)
* FPGAs, ASICs, 5G edge workload chips, Integrated Xe GPUs
* Habana AI chips which are 15x faster than GPU for neural network training (AWS uses them)
* Entering gaming GPU market
* OneAPI -- Intel's open-source, open-standards answer to proprietary CUDA from Nvidia
* Investing in business left and right
* Has maintained its revenue and growth despite increasing competition and unfavorable circumstances
* Fortress balance sheet to weather any downturn in the economy
* Very important for U.S. National Security
* Mobileye -- a leader in self-driving technology

Based on current 2020 revenue and cash flow and projecting a very conservative 5% growth rate for 5 years in the future and then 2.5% terminal growth, Intel is already worth \~$63 assuming a 10% return per year. The margin of safety is just 10% right now so I'd wait for some more weakness but Intel was a screaming buy at $45 several months ago.

author: polaarbear
body:
The Ice Lake 10nm Xeons are using a COAG process 100%.  And yes the yield issues are real.

Something I should have said higher up in the thread is that I don't think the node is Intel's problem.  Their bigger issue is that they don't have a CPU architecture that can compete right now.  The node wouldn't matter so much if the architecture was decent.

That's why the big.LITTLE designs and chip-stacking stuff is interesting.  They are pouring money into precisely the kind of research it takes to overcome these problems.

Intel's market cap is over 230 billion dollars. AMD's is like 93 billion.  That's today, right now, with all the problems taken into account.  They have the money to "fix" this problem.  It sucks that it takes time but it's not like they can just call up a guy and ask for a better CPU lithographer.  It's all cutting-edge few-of-a-kind type tech, and I guarantee Intel is going to find a way to surprise people sooner rather than later.  I'm not saying don't buy AMD. I own 3 AMD gaming PCs in my house. I own a 5700XT, a 1060, and a 1650.  Buy whatever hardware meets your needs, but lets not fanboy into oblivion just to be part of the circle jerk.

author: Mail_Order_Lutefisk
body:
Just like in '99 and 2000, there is some game changing tech out there. 

This one might ring some bells, but I think Netflix is on the path to being the next AOL. Maybe that's an exaggeration, but I wouldn't touch the stock. There are deep content pools that legacy studios are putting together that will really eat into Netflix, including, ironically enough, the assets of TimeWarner formerly owned by AOL which are now the bundle that is HBOMax. 

Any company that isn't an existing conglomerate (like Amazon) that has the word "cloud" in its short description worries me. Don't get me wrong, the so-called "cloud" is really cool, but I suspect it will be like the old telcos that spent tens of billions burying fiber. Of course, in the long haul that fiber was needed and it was critical for rolling out the data hungry streaming model, but a huge percentage of it got placed and then sat dormant. It absolutely buried companies that were high fliers (you have to understand it wasn't just a dot com bubble, there was an entire telecom bubble as well). A lot of stuff with "cloud" in it will probably find a similar fate. There will be winners just like Amazon eventually gained the title of internet commerce king, but the carcasses of the dead will lay across Wall Street only to be forgotten in a few years. 

One that I remember thinking was a turd was PLUG. Look at the max chart on that thing. I still wouldn't buy that. Maybe I'm totally wrong, maybe not. I think TSLA is also overvalued. I'm not saying it's a bad company or anything, but its valuation metrics are way out of whack. 

You have to understand in that era guys would go on CNBC and talk about some new internet IPO was worth x billion because it had y million "eyeballs." I'm not exaggerating. They would multiply page views by 2 and use it as a metric for valuation. That whole thing to me felt like the bigger idiot theory taken to the extreme, but even that feels more reputable than the people who push crypto on CNBC. 

I have cash. I want to deploy it because of inflation risks, but there's virtually nothing I want to touch right now so I've just been nibbling on Boomer stocks and swing trading SPY options. 

Oh, and one other thing. Funds. Back then Janus Twenty was all the rage. They had closed it to new investors. People would brag that they were in it. It had all the high flyers. AOL, Cisco, JDSUniphase, Intel, Microsoft and Oracle. That reminds me of that ARK fund or whatever it is called. Again, not everything in the J20 was a terrible company, but valuations got so out of whack that things like INTC have never returned to their highs and MSFT and ORCL, while good companies, were dead money for over a decade. I think a company like TSLA has the chance to find itself in that sort of company where the stock takes a decade plus to touch its ATH again.

author: proverbialbunny
body:
To get in when the P/E is that low it has to be right after a recession when fear is still high and people are afraid of a double bottom, or the company is in turmoil and you see it will be fine.

Me, I just wait passively for some product or service I like and then I buy it because I like it.  It's changing my life so I value it.  I don't look at P/E or anything else.  I don't try to make a buck, I just want to support a company I think highly of.  So far I bought Google and Nvidia during the google IPO (Nvidia for a stock market competition at the time, not as a value buy.), Apple when they switched to Intel processors, AMD when the Ryzen 2 was announced, Tesla when I was giving a ride in a model S early on, and right now I'm taste testing Beyond meat's new version 3.0 meat to see if to me it is a company I want to support.  I also want to get in on Toyota but I'm afraid of the Japanese stock market, but I value them as a company too.

The trick is not to exceed 10% of your portfolio for value buys (the rest goes into index funds /r/boggleheads style).  I value these companies as a consumer, not for profit reasons.  If I tried to profit I'd be chasing P/E ratios and other order book metrics trying to penny pinch and find the best deal.  That isn't me.  I don't want a second job.  I just want to support what I love, and that is a valid kind of value investing.

author: jaboyles
body:
I think everyone is an insider in their own industry. For example, if you work in construction, you learned about rising lumber prices before everyone else, and know which companies could keep up with the demand. If you work in airlines you see when traffic is starting to increase, and which companies are handling the rapidly changing environment the best. If you work with tech, you knew when AMD finally became a serious competitor to Intel. 

If you have a hunch, add the stock to your watchlist, compare their quarter earnings performances to their yearly price chart, and keep your eye on volume. Webull and Robinhood have everthing you need to know even if you don't buy through them. It's amazing to me how many people keep buying SNDL with 100 million in volume every day. That stock is being scalped to death. Low volume and strong price support is the time to buy in. It's an indicator that everyone holding the stock is long, and it's the last thing they'll liquidate because they know it's worth more than it's current trading price. The flatter it trades the cheaper options are on red days too.

author: CalligrapherOneTwo3
body:
Here are a few points which may or may not be helpful to you from my perspective regarding buying this alternative asset class, cold storage, taxation, and the cheapest method of accumulating/procuring it in Canada:

1. Personally, I only buy on the Newton app since they currently have the lowest purchasing fees out of all of the available exchanges in Canada. Newton's average spread varies from 0.50% to 0.60% which is 2-3 times cheaper than most of the other available exchanges that are available to us as Canadians. I also use the ShakePay app to earn free Bitcoin on a daily basis by physically shaking my phone once a day. Trust me, I know that sounds ridiculous, stupid, and suspicious, but ShakePay is a legitimate company based out of Montréal which is regulated by both FINTRAC and AMF while it is also legally licensed as a Money Service Business. I never actually buy from ShakePay because of their high purchasing spreads (which is approximately 1.75%) and I simply use them for the free daily accumulation of Bitcoin. Anyone who uses ShakePay can attest to this and easily confirm their legitimacy. 

2. Since I actually want to own the underlying asset, I withdraw my Bitcoin from both of those exchanges and I put my assets into a cold storage wallet. In Canada, this is currently the cheapest method of accumulating Bitcoin and truly owning the assets by storing them "offline" in a cold storage wallet. However, in order to unlock the ShakingSats feature in ShakePay to earn free Bitcoin, you will need to be referred as per their current terms and conditions. I can assist you with that in addition to answering any general questions that you may have regarding buying, selling, converting, and taxation-related issues if you want to message me directly as I am always willing to help educate others in this space with whatever knowledge and/or experience that I have gained over the years.

3. If you want tax free capital gains, you can buy QBTC, BTCX or BTCC in your TFSA. For QBTC, it is certainly expensive in terms of its historical premiums (5%-20%) and MER (1.95%); however, if you are long/bullish in Bitcoin as an alternative asset class, then perhaps it does not really matter. With that said, you do not truly own Bitcoin with any of those because they are a fund; and therefore, you own shares of the fund and not Bitcoin itself. As the saying goes and as you may have heard if you have done your due diligence: "not your keys, not your Bitcoin". As such, you run and operate with all of the associated risks of leaving your coins on an exchange which is why I choose to own the real thing and use a cold storage wallet. The products mentioned above are not insured. Big risk, but tax free in a TFSA.

4. You may have heard of a Canadian company named Quadriga. In short, many investors did not truly own their Bitcoin with them since Quadriga sold "entitlements to receive crypto assets or fiat currency from Quadriga" while Quadriga held the "keys" to the real Bitcoin and investors lost around 135 million dollars CAD, but up to 250 million dollars CAD according to Wikipedia. This is verifiable information, a famous story, and a perfect example of "not your keys, not your Bitcoin" as well as a lack of insurance of clients. Also, as of April, 22, 2021, Thodex, an exchange with 400,000 users went offline while Interpol issued a red notice for its CEO who mysteriously disappeared. According to Fortune,  an international manhunt is currently underway to locate the CEO and secure $2 billion in digital tokens he allegedly embezzled from Thodex.

5. Unfortunately, with BTCC, QBTC and WealthSimple Crypto, you cannot take your Bitcoin off of their exchanges because, again, you do not truly own Bitcoin with them. Rather, you own shares of the fund whereas those organizations truly own the asset since they have the "keys". They are the ones who own the real asset (Bitcoin) and simply run the fund with the Bitcoin backing that fund as they make money through their ridiculously overpriced premiums and spread/fees (WealthSimple's spread is around 1.5-2.0% if not higher and BTCC's MER is about 1%).

6. In regards to taxes, if you truly own the asset (Bitcoin), it is subject to capital appreciation tax whenever you trigger a taxable event such as selling it, buying things with it, and/or converting crypto-to-crypto. As such, you need to be prudent in your bookkeeping behavior and calculate your "adjusted cost base" for each transaction. There is no legal requirement forcing you to calculate your "adjusted cost base" for each transaction, but it just saves you a lot of headaches later on when you need to pay taxes. This is no different than investing in traditional equities in a taxable account after you have maxed out your TFSA, RRSP, RESP, etc.

7. Before you invest in anything regardless of the asset class, make sure you understand what you are putting your money towards, understand your risk tolerance, understand the proper asset allocation percentages for your risk tolerance, and formulate a clear plan of what you want to achieve. For me, the biggest investment is not really the Bitcoin itself, but rather, it is in the underlying technology and innovation of the blockchain infrastructure which serves as a massive global public ledger leading to the decentralization of this digital currency as well as its invincibility and independence from overbearing governing bodies whereby the Bitcoin unit itself simply has a monetary value relative to fiat currency. Disclaimer: I am super long Bitcoin.

Now, here are some general points of interests to help you understand cold storage wallets:

1. There is a big misconception that if you decide to operate as your own bank (i.e.truly own your Bitcoin) and use a cold storage wallet device (i.e. physical hardware connected via USB to your PC), that your assets (Bitcoin) will be transferred and stored onto that physical USB device. This is the part that confuses a lot of people. In short, Bitcoin is not stored on that device, it will never be stored there, and this is because Bitcoin can never leave its "blockchain".

2. So, what does your cold storage device do? The device allows you to have a "key" to your asset (Bitcoin) on the blockchain. How is this "key" established? Without going too deep into the technical aspects, when you initially setup the hardware wallet device, you will be given a 24-word "seed phrase" and it is literally 24 words. From a computer science perspective, this 24-word "seed phrase" actually represents and is transcribed into a huge series/string of alphanumeric characters. This 24-word "seed phrase" is essentially your "keys" to your assets on the blockchain.

3. Your 24-word "seed phrase" is what is most important if you decide to act as your own bank and truly own Bitcoin since this is what gives you access to it. It does not matter if you lose your physical device and it does not matter if your physical device was destroyed. Why? Again, your assets are on the blockchain and not on the physical device. So, if you lose your physical device, you can simply replace it with another one (and this can be one from a different manufacturer too), set it up with your original 24-word "seed phrase" and you will once again have access to your assets since they are on the blockchain. In essence, never lose your "keys" because then you will have truly lost your Bitcoin. 

4. As you can probably see now, your 24-word "seed phrase" is extremely important (and more important than the physical hardware device itself). Therefore, when you first take note of your 24-word "seed phrase" during the initial setup of your physical hardware device, make sure that no one is watching, there are no cameras around you (including your mobile phone), etc. Only you should know your "keys". Never type it out on any digital device, never e-mail it to yourself, never take a photo of it, never upload it to a cloud database such as Google Docs and never try to encrypt it and put it on a regular USB drive. You want this 24-word seed phrase as private as possible. So, if anyone/anything asks you for your "keys", never give it out. Period.

5. What is a blockchain? It is a transparent, public, and append-only ledger. Basically, you can add data to this transparent, open, and public ledger, but you can never edit/delete previously established data within it. This is executed by a mechanism of consensus creation between geographically scattered parties (i.e. computers) that do not need to trust each other. The parties only need to trust the consensus mechanism itself. Blockchain infrastructure relies on some form of challenge such that no single party on the network can consistently and systematically solve this challenge more than everyone else on the network. This randomizes the consensus mechanism of confirming transactions and ensures that no single party can force the blockchain ledger to accept a particular entry onto the ledger that others disagree with. This is a peer-to-peer network that can maintain updates to the ledger and verify those updates in such a way that it is impossible to defraud and impossible to alter an entry after it has been confirmed via consensus.

I sincerely hope that this has been helpful to you and good luck!

Most other treadmills are lower to the ground(6 inches) and use a continuous belt for motion. The Peloton tread uses a slat belt which can catch things in between and is 12 inches off the ground. Other treadmills are also lighter(220lbs) and usually have a mechanism to fold upwards so if something gets under it will lift up, the pton tread is 450lbs. Other treadmills also have emergency shut off keys and locks, the tread just has a touchscreen and no emergency shut off.

For perspective, the pton treadmill caught a 6yr old kid under it and killed them, not like a small dog or infant.

author: the_snook
body:
> Why would international investors put their money on a database controlled by the US government

Because they trust the US government more than they trust the distributed network to be resilient to 51% and other attacks from adversarial states.

Additionally, they may have no choice if they want to continue to invest in US government instruments. The US could move all government bond settlements to a blockchain. Why would they do that? It's cheaper. You authorize half a dozen large banks to participate in the quorum and turn down all the government-run infrastructure except the bit that signs the keys of the participants.

author: dorflinuse
body:
You have to distinguish between exchanges and wallets. Some exchanges actually provide you with the coins, other just provide you with exposure to it and give you some kind of object tied to the price action but never the actual transferable coin.

For exchanges that allow you to buy the coins, just look at [https://coinmarketcap.com/currencies/bitcoin/markets/](https://coinmarketcap.com/currencies/bitcoin/markets/) 

Etoro, Robinhood and a few others just allow you some exposure.

Furthermore, exchanges give you acces to the coins, but they are never yours, they still can exert influence on them such as freezing the account and you will not be able to transfer or trade. The second part is much more relevant. These exchanges can be hacked and your coins can be transferred without your consent. In crypto we say, not your keys, not your coins. 

Wallets are a bit tougher to explain, it's your personal bank account which is accessible through software.  I'll try to explain it buy using Cardano. 

A Cardano wallet is accessible through Yoroi and Daedalus and those two allow you to make transactions on the network (sending / staking). So your adress is where it is stored, but the software allows you to mutate the contents. 

Now.. if you are still reading :)

Whichever is good for you depends on what you want. First you have to realise the fees.. 

Each exchange has fees, trading fees and transfer fees as well as minimum transfer amounts, this scheme varies. Depending on which coins you are interested in, you will find a subset of exchanges with their own set of values for this. 

Second, some coins allow for staking (you can roughly translate this as a short term fixed deposit which gives you a return on investment). This can be done on some exchanges (Bittrex, Binance, Coinbase, Kraken), but again, they facilitate, they take. There are some cases where it is preferable though, i.e. when you don't have the minimum required amount to stake.

Well that's all for now :) If you want more info, send a DM or visit us at the cryptocurrency sub.

Opened a 0DTE 4100/4120 on 4/14. Was still stinging from the $4k loss a week before. Watched it dropping. author: Pe1per
body:
>60% of the hashrate is in China, so China can just take over BTC or turn it off, if it wants.

Not true anymore, hashrate in china recently got below 50% because the US and other places are starting to step up their game. This will only continue as more and more serious institutions start to get it and don't want china to control them. 

>The ecological impact of running computers to support BTC is insane and currently unsustainable.

Energy consumption of Bitcoin is lower then our current monetary system (banks, visa etc) in relative terms. There's also a clear trend to sustainable energy usage since mining is location independent and is a way to profit off of otherwise unusable land and wasted energy (deserts/surplus of the power grid etc.)

>Nobody knows the exact origin of BTC, so nobody really knows if there is a back door to hack

Knowing who Satoshi is is irrelevant in terms of hacking. The entire code of the protocol is public since it started. Bitcoin is an open source project and anyone can look at the code if they want to. There are no backdoors and there's no way to build one unless you want the whole world to see it. 

>there are a number of early early adopters that hold a huge amount and can tank the market anytime they decide to sell their billions of dollars worth of BTC

Only point that's fair imo. Although there's something to be said that the market can tank it by now and it won't be the end of Bitcoin. Also I doubt these individuals would voluntarily trigger a market crash by selling billions at once. They obviously believe in Bitcoin's future or lost their keys otherwise they wouldn't have stayed committed to their holdings for this long. 

>I think blockchain is a tech that is here to stay, but current versions are basically beta tests.

Smart contract platforms and everything build on them are still in beta/early adopter territory but Bitcoin isn't. Banks and the biggest financial institutions don't adopt technologies that are in "beta" Bitcoin is a trillion dollar asset and on it's way to cross the chasm to the early majority.

author: introvertedhedgehog
body:
Well firstly his ideas hardly addresses the points I illustrated. Interesting but full of conjecture and vague suppositions, typical for that kind of pitch "people disagree with me but this is because they are stupid and are part of the machine"

 If VCs where prone to believe every similar line of reason they read like Dan's they would invest after every one of thousands of hockey stick presentations they see. Here is one such gem based on emotional appeal to the outsider:

"The idea that Satoshi perfectly crafted Bitcoin on the first try is unfathomable for them to consider." 

To which the first commentor correctly replies "Because it's unfathomable that this is true" and there you have the summary of the two sides of the argument.

Even a brief browse through the Wikipedia entry for Bitcoin will tell you as much based on its history.

There are so many other problems with BtC but let's just choose one and let's also apply another line if reasoning: how secure is it in a physical sense? People are keeping their keys on physical media in safety deposit boxes at multiple banks because they are rightly concerned people can and would kill them for their Bitcoin or otherwise steal it. Many people who used services for their wallet have been burnt hard. We have laws about the fiet money proceeds of such crimes but people who own BTC do well to be concerned. Whose jurisdiction does solving a theft of Bitcoin actually fall under? Where exactly is Satoshi if he is even a real person? If he is not dead it's pretty dangerous to be him.

The truth is that BTC is flawed and will be changed/replaced as people solve problems with it. As such it will become obsolete or be updated and when that happens it will be vulnerable and Dans reasoning is flawed on this basis.

I have no doubt there is utility for crypto. I just think investing in any particular technology as an investment asset will be demonstrated to be a huge mistake in 15 years when when we look back on the crypto bubble of 20xx. Many of the Dotcom companies had value there was still a bubble. Except now with crypto we have perfected this bubble. For Dotcom and firms pretended to have value and products or services. 

Bottom line: Dan is invested

author: CalligrapherOneTwo3
body:
Yes, as a Canadian, there are multiple exchanges available to us such as Newton, ShakePay, NDAX, WealthSimple Crypto, and some Bitcoin/Ethereum ETFs. Here are a few points which may or may not be helpful to you from my perspective regarding buying this alternative asset class, cold storage, taxation, and the cheapest method of accumulating/procuring it in Canada:

1. Personally, I only buy on the Newton app since they currently have the lowest purchasing fees out of all of the available exchanges in Canada. Newton's average spread varies from 0.50% to 0.60% which is 2-3 times cheaper than most of the other available exchanges that are available to us as Canadians. I also use the ShakePay app to earn free Bitcoin on a daily basis by physically shaking my phone once a day. Trust me, I know that sounds ridiculous, stupid, and suspicious, but ShakePay is a legitimate company based out of Montréal which is regulated by both FINTRAC and AMF while it is also legally licensed as a Money Service Business. I never actually buy from ShakePay because of their high purchasing spreads (which is approximately 1.75%) and I simply use them for the free daily accumulation of Bitcoin. Anyone who uses ShakePay can attest to this and easily confirm their legitimacy. 

2. Since I actually want to own the underlying asset, I withdraw my Bitcoin from both of those exchanges and I put my assets into a cold storage wallet. In Canada, this is currently the cheapest method of accumulating Bitcoin and truly owning the assets by storing them "offline" in a cold storage wallet. However, in order to unlock the ShakingSats feature in ShakePay to earn free Bitcoin, you will need to be referred as per their current terms and conditions. I can assist you with that in addition to answering any general questions that you may have regarding buying, selling, converting, and taxation-related issues if you want to message me directly as I am always willing to help educate others in this space with whatever knowledge and/or experience that I have gained over the years.

3. If you want tax free capital gains, you can buy BTCX, ETHX or BTCC in your TFSA. With that said, you do not truly own crypto with any of those because they are a fund; and therefore, you own shares of the fund and not the asset itself. As the saying goes and as you may have heard if you have done your due diligence: "not your keys, not your crypto". As such, you run and operate with all of the associated risks of leaving your coins on an exchange which is why I choose to own the real thing and use a cold storage wallet. The products mentioned above are not insured. Big risk, but tax free/deferred in a TFSA/RRSP.

4. You may have heard of a Canadian company named Quadriga. In short, many investors did not truly own their Bitcoin with them since Quadriga sold "entitlements to receive crypto assets or fiat currency from Quadriga" while Quadriga held the "keys" to the real Bitcoin and investors lost around 135 million dollars CAD, but up to 250 million dollars CAD according to Wikipedia. This is verifiable information, a famous story, and a perfect example of "not your keys, not your Bitcoin" as well as a lack of insurance of clients. Also, as of April, 22, 2021, Thodex, an exchange with 400,000 users went offline while Interpol issued a red notice for its CEO who mysteriously disappeared. According to Fortune,  an international manhunt is currently underway to locate the CEO and secure $2 billion in digital tokens he allegedly embezzled from Thodex.

5. Unfortunately, with BTCC, ETHX, and WealthSimple Crypto, you cannot take your Bitcoin off of their exchanges because, again, you do not truly own Bitcoin with them. Rather, you own shares of the fund whereas those organizations truly own the asset since they have the "keys". They are the ones who own the real asset (crypto) and simply run the fund with the crypto backing that fund as they make money through their ridiculously overpriced premiums and spread/fees (WealthSimple's spread is around 1.5-2.0% if not higher and BTCC's MER is about 1%).

6. In regards to taxes, if you truly own the asset (crypto), it is subject to capital appreciation tax whenever you trigger a taxable event such as selling it, buying things with it, and/or converting crypto-to-crypto. As such, you need to be prudent in your bookkeeping behavior and calculate your "adjusted cost base" for each transaction. There is no legal requirement forcing you to calculate your "adjusted cost base" for each transaction, but it just saves you a lot of headaches later on when you need to pay taxes. This is no different than investing in traditional equities in a taxable account after you have maxed out your TFSA, RRSP, RESP, etc.

7. Before you invest in anything regardless of the asset class, make sure you understand what you are putting your money towards, understand your risk tolerance, understand the proper asset allocation percentages for your risk tolerance, and formulate a clear plan of what you want to achieve. For me, the biggest investment is not really Bitcoin itself, but rather, it is in the underlying technology and innovation of the blockchain infrastructure which serves as a massive global public ledger leading to the decentralization of this digital currency as well as its invincibility and independence from overbearing governing bodies whereby the Bitcoin unit itself simply has a monetary value relative to fiat currency. Disclaimer: I am irresponsibly long Bitcoin/Ethereum.

Now, here are some general points of interests to help you understand cold storage wallets:

1. There is a big misconception that if you decide to operate as your own bank (i.e.truly own your Bitcoin) and use a cold storage wallet device (i.e. physical hardware connected via USB to your PC), that your assets (Bitcoin) will be transferred and stored onto that physical USB device. This is the part that confuses a lot of people. In short, Bitcoin is not stored on that device, it will never be stored there, and this is because Bitcoin can never leave its "blockchain".

2. So, what does your cold storage device do? The device allows you to have a "key" to your asset (Bitcoin) on the blockchain. How is this "key" established? Without going too deep into the technical aspects, when you initially setup the hardware wallet device, you will be given a 24-word "seed phrase" and it is literally 24 words. From a computer science perspective, this 24-word "seed phrase" actually represents and is transcribed into a huge series/string of alphanumeric characters. This 24-word "seed phrase" is essentially your "keys" to your assets on the blockchain.

3. Your 24-word "seed phrase" is what is most important if you decide to act as your own bank and truly own Bitcoin since this is what gives you access to it. It does not matter if you lose your physical device and it does not matter if your physical device was destroyed. Why? Again, your assets are on the blockchain and not on the physical device. So, if you lose your physical device, you can simply replace it with another one (and this can be one from a different manufacturer too), set it up with your original 24-word "seed phrase" and you will once again have access to your assets since they are on the blockchain. In essence, never lose your "keys" because then you will have truly lost your Bitcoin. 

4. As you can probably see now, your 24-word "seed phrase" is extremely important (and more important than the physical hardware device itself). Therefore, when you first take note of your 24-word "seed phrase" during the initial setup of your physical hardware device, make sure that no one is watching, there are no cameras around you (including your mobile phone), etc. Only you should know your "keys". Never type it out on any digital device, never e-mail it to yourself, never take a photo of it, never upload it to a cloud database such as Google Docs and never try to encrypt it and put it on a regular USB drive. You want this 24-word seed phrase as private as possible. So, if anyone/anything asks you for your "keys", never give it out. Period.

5. What is a blockchain? It is a transparent, public, and append-only ledger. Basically, you can add data to this transparent, open, and public ledger, but you can never edit/delete previously established data within it. This is executed by a mechanism of consensus creation between geographically scattered parties (i.e. computers) that do not need to trust each other. The parties only need to trust the consensus mechanism itself. Blockchain infrastructure relies on some form of challenge such that no single party on the network can consistently and systematically solve this challenge more than everyone else on the network. This randomizes the consensus mechanism of confirming transactions and ensures that no single party can force the blockchain ledger to accept a particular entry onto the ledger that others disagree with. This is a peer-to-peer network that can maintain updates to the ledger and verify those updates in such a way that it is impossible to defraud and impossible to alter an entry after it has been confirmed via consensus.

I sincerely hope that this has been helpful to you and good luck!

author: ShittyStockPicker
body:
The microchip market itself is exploding with demand. Everything, I mean fucking everything is getting microchips now. Listen to the conference calls. All the chip manufacturers are building new foundries to handle the growth in demand.   


Long story short, people are finding more uses for AI, and better AI requires more powerful chips. Sure, the stock is trading at a high P/E. That doesn't mean it's not on my pullback radar.   


Value investing for me is all about buying and holding for 10+ years. I expect the demand for chips to power AI skyrocketing over the next 10 years. Self-driving cars, automated factories, airborne pizza delivery, robotic pilots, algorithms for predicting consumer behavior, automated logistics, personal health AI wearables, kill bots to dominate the battlefield. There are uses for AI that we still haven't found yet, and all of those new uses are going to require lots of chips.   


Even now, chip manufacturers are building new foundries to meet the demand. I'm so fucking bullish on chip manufacturing over the next 10 years. I'm thinking about switching out some of my VGT tech etf funds specifically to a semiconductor ETF to hold for the next 10 years.
